answer_html: This also means that \(f\) has a local maximum at \(x=0\).
answer_latex: This also means that $f$ has a local maximum at $x=0$.
hints_html: We determine where \(f\) is increasing or decreasing by looking at the sign (positive or negative) of the first derivative.
hints_latex:
We determine where $f$ is increasing or decreasing by looking at the
sign (positive or negative) of the first derivative.
hints_raw: We determine where <math>f</math> is increasing or decreasing by looking at the sign (positive or negative) of the first derivative.
question: 8 (d)
sols_html:
To determine where \(f\) is increasing or decreasing, we look at the sign of the first derivative. The first derivative, calculated using the chain rule, is:

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{-2x}{4-x^2} = \frac{2x}{x^2-4}\end{aligned}\]

It has critical points at \(x = 0, -2, 2\). The values -2 and 2 are not part of the domain, but x = 0 is. We first note that the denominator is always negative on the domain \(\displaystyle (-2,2)\). Hence, the sign of the derivative is always the opposite sign of the numerator. For x < 0 we see that \(\displaystyle f'(x) > 0\), while for x > 0 we see that \(\displaystyle f'(x) < 0\).

Hence, \(f\) is increasing on (-2,0) and decreasing on (0,2).

”Note. This also means that \(f\) has a local maximum at \(x=0\).
sols_latex:
To determine where $f$ is increasing or decreasing, we look at the sign
of the first derivative. The first derivative, calculated using the
chain rule, is:

\begin{align*}
f'(x) = \frac{-2x}{4-x^2} = \frac{2x}{x^2-4}
\end{align*}

It has critical points at $x = 0, -2, 2$. The values \emph{-2} and
\emph{2} are not part of the domain, but \emph{x = 0} is. We first note
that the denominator is always negative on the domain
$\displaystyle (-2,2)$. Hence, the sign of the derivative is always the
opposite sign of the numerator. For \emph{x \textless{} 0} we see that
$\displaystyle f'(x) > 0$, while for \emph{x \textgreater{} 0} we see
that $\displaystyle f'(x) < 0$.

Hence, $f$ is increasing on \emph{(-2,0)} and decreasing on
\emph{(0,2)}.

''Note. This also means that $f$ has a local maximum at $x=0$.
sols_raw:
To determine where <math>f</math> is increasing or decreasing, we look at the sign of the first derivative.  The first derivative, calculated using the chain rule, is:

:<math>f'(x) = \frac{-2x}{4-x^2} = \frac{2x}{x^2-4}</math>

It has critical points at <math>x = 0, -2, 2</math>. The values ''-2'' and ''2'' are not part of the domain, but ''x = 0'' is. We first note that the denominator is always negative on the domain <math>\displaystyle (-2,2)</math>. Hence, the sign of the derivative is always the opposite sign of the numerator. For ''x < 0'' we see that <math>\displaystyle f'(x) > 0</math>, while for ''x > 0'' we see that <math>\displaystyle f'(x) < 0</math>.

<div style="color:blue">Hence, <math>f</math> is increasing on ''(-2,0)'' and decreasing on ''(0,2)''.</div>
''Note. This also means that <math>f</math> has a local maximum at <math>x=0</math>.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)\end{aligned}\]

Determine where \(f\) is increasing and where it is decreasing.
statement_raw:
Let

:<math> \displaystyle
f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)
</math>

Determine where &fnof; is increasing and where it is decreasing.
